official-title.#text:
To direct the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to establish
		  a standardized scheduling policy for veterans enrolled in the health care
		  system of the Department of Veterans Affairs, and for other
		  purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Veterans Access to Timely Medical
			 Appointments Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

is
			 statutorily obligated to provide eligible individuals who served in the Armed
			 Forces with access to health care and benefits provided by the
related to such service.
has given the

the
			 goal of scheduling a primary care medical appointment within seven days of the
			 date requested by the patient and or the provider and scheduling a specialty
			 care medical appointment within fourteen days of the date requested by the
			 patient and or the provider.

to accurately schedule and provide timely access to medical
			 appointments is critical to ensure the health care needs of veterans are met
			 and medical conditions do not worsen because of delays in receiving medical
			 treatment.

found that medical appointment wait
			 times reported by the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Comptroller General of the United States

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: of the

are
			 unreliable.

found that without reliable measurement of how long patients are
			 waiting for medical appointments, the

is not able to identify areas
			 that need improvement and therefore cannot mitigate problems that contribute to
			 wait times.

found that the unreliable data and measures for wait times create a
			 discrepancy between the positive results the

publishes and what
			 veterans actually experience.
found that the

inconsistently implements
			 its scheduling policy across medical centers of the

, which impedes
			 scheduling timely medical appointments.

found that oversight of compliance with such scheduling policy, such as
			 ensuring the completion of required scheduler training, was inconsistent across
			 facilities.
found that the management by the

of telephone service,
			 including lack of staff dedicated to answering phones and unreturned phone
			 calls, impede veterans’ access to timely medical appointments.
reviewed by the

, patient
			 complaints regarding unreturned phone calls ranked among the top two categories
			 of complaints during fiscal year 2012.

text.#text:
Among the four
			 medical centers of the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: found that in January 2012, the

distributed best practices for telephone access that, if implemented, could
			 help improve telephone access to clinical care.

is
			 not meeting the statutory obligations of the

to provide veterans with
			 timely access to medical appointments so that such veterans can receive
			 benefits and health care by the
in a timely manner.

header.#text:
Improvement of
			 medical appointment scheduling policy for veterans

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall implement a standardized policy to ensure that a veteran enrolled
			 in the health care system established under
, is able to schedule—

text.#text:
Not later than 180
			 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the

primary care
			 medical appointments within seven days of the date requested by the veteran or
			 the health care provider on behalf of the veteran; and

specialty care
			 medical appointments within 14 days of the date requested by the veteran or the
			 health care provider on behalf of the veteran.

text.#text:
will
			 not be subject to interpretation or prone to scheduler error; and

with reliable data regarding the length of time that veterans are

that the

carries out uniform procedures with respect to

text.#text:
issue detailed
			 guidance to the directors of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks to ensure

who have completed required training are allowed to

ensure that only

make public annual

Not

			 180-day period thereafter, the

may reprogram funds and
			 allocate or transfer staff and other resources within the

and the Veterans Integrated Service Network to ensure that each

shall
			 direct each medical center of the

to provide oversight of telephone
			 access and implement the best practices outlined in the telephone systems

, including, at a
			 minimum, practices to ensure that—

text.#text:
calls are answered in a timely manner and
			 the messages of patients will have a return call not later than 24 hours after
			 the patient leaves the message; and

a
			 call center at each such medical center is properly staffed to meet the needs
			 of the veteran population served by the medical center.
